summary.seg: Cambridge, University Library, MS. Dd.4.24 (Dd) is one of the earliest surviving manuscripts of the Canterbury Tales. Textually, Dd contains the 'canonical' tales of the Canterbury Tales running from the General Prologue to the Canon's Yeoman's Tale, but the last part of the manuscript is defective, and it is impossible to say how Dd ended. The content and order of the tales in Dd are very close to California, San Marino, Huntington Library MS. El. 26 C 9 - also known as the 'Ellesmere manuscript' (El) - another famous manuscript of this poem which is often used in modern editions of this poem. There is evidence in Dd that the scribe had to make decisions in the sequence of the tales as well as in the inclusion of contested passages. For instance, the missing paragraph between ff. 105v-106r at the beginning of the Merchant's Tale indicates that a paper leaf was replaced (Da Rold, 2003). The scribe of Dd also included a rarely corrected version of the extra passages in the Wife of Bath's Prologue (Da Rold, 2007), which supports the thesis that the Dd scribe was working collaboratively in a location not too distant from a supply of exemplars.

The manuscript was produced at the turn of the fifteenth century. It is the only surviving early witness of this Chaucerian text to be written on paper. Paper by the beginning of the fifteenth century was a familiar object in English book production and beyond. And yet, despite many attempts, the paper-stocks in Dd have yet not been identified with certainty.

The paper is a thin, laid, watermarked paper folded in a quarto format. From an approximate calculation each sheet measured c. 580 mm x 400 mm before folding but after it was trimmed. This is a large size of paper, of a type known as 'Royal'. Accounts tell us that Royal paper was more expensive than other types of paper and it was bought by clerks in several writing environments, including the royal household, with evidence from about 1350s. Iconographically, Dd's paper stocks include watermarks comprising twin dragons in Quires 1-8 and a dog in Quire 9. Despite much discussion, it is still impossible to identify these watermarks in published albums because the size of the paper is not the same. Those watermarks that have been often compared to the one in Dd are imprinted on 'Chancery' paper (a smaller size of paper) and therefore cannot have come from the same mould. The only exact matches that I have identified to date relate to the dog paper stock. They can be found in other two manuscripts in Cambridge University Library's collections: MS Ii.5.41, a copy of John Trevisa's translation of Bartholomeus Anglicus, De Proprietaribus Rerum, ff. 37-38 and MS Dd.1.1, a miscellany including a copy of the Northern Homilies, ff. 16-215.

The manuscript bears the possible name of its scribe, 'Wytton,' inscribed on several folios: at the end of the Knight's Tale (f. 39r), the Miller's Tale (f. 47r) and the Summoner's Tale (f. 92r). Dd has often puzzled scholars, who on the one hand have praised the quality of its text and some of its codicological features, but on the other have considered the manuscript as the work of an amateur in a provincial milieu, probably a university student (Manly and Rickert, 1940, 1, p. 105). However, a recent and more compelling argument suggests that the scribe of Dd likely belonged to a network of scribes operating in London, with access to informed insights into the early development of the Canterbury Tales text and the genesis of its tale-order, shedding light on the literary and cultural milieu of the time. Dd opens a window into the rich context of medieval literary culture, offering an enduring legacy to the creation and circulation of the Canterbury Tales and its place in literary history.

Orietta da Rold
Professor of Medieval Literature and Manuscript Studies
University of Cambridge

msContents.textLang: Middle English, with some rubrics and marginal annotations in Latin. Not in LALME, but localised to London area (Thaisen and Da Rold (2009)). Previously localised to western Norfolk, Ely and Cambridgeshire (Manly and Rickert (1940))

msItem.title: Canterbury Tales
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.textLang: Middle English, with some rubrics and marginal annotations in Latin. Not in LALME, but localised to London area (Thaisen and Da Rold (2009)). Previously localised to western Norfolk, Ely and Cambridgeshire (Manly and Rickert (1940))

msItem.title: General Prologue
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 6r: though a wyndewe / had nouȝt a shoo
msItem.explicit: 13r: This tale a non / and seide on þis manere

msItem.title: Knight's Tale
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.rubric: 13r: Iamque domos patrias scithice post aspera gentis / prelia laurigero et cetera / Heere bigynneth / the knyghtes tale
msItem.incipit: 13r: Whilom there was / as olde stories tellen vs
msItem.explicit: 39r: Thus endeth Palamon / and Emelye / And god saue al / this fair companye
msItem.note: 'Amen quod Wytton' in margin next to I.3108 (f.

msItem.title: Miller's Prologue / Knight-Miller link
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 39r: Whan that the knyght / had thus his tale I told In al the companye / ne was þere ȝong ne old
msItem.explicit: 39v: A vyseth ȝow / and put me ouȝt of blame / And eke / men shuln nat make / ernest of game

msItem.title: Miller's Tale
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 40r: Whilom there was dwellyng / in Oxenford / A riche gnof / that gestes held to bord
msItem.explicit: 47r: And Nicholas is skalded / in the toute / This tale is don / and god saue al the route
msItem.note: 'quod Wytton' in the margin of f. 47r.

msItem.title: Reeve's Prologue
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.rubric: 47v: ...and bygynneth the prologe of the Reve
msItem.incipit: 47v: Whanne folk han laughen / at þis nyce cas / Of Absoloun / and hende Nicholas
msItem.explicit: 48r: He can wel in myn eye / sen a stalke / But in his owen / he can nat sen a balke

msItem.title: Reeve's Tale
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 48r: At Trompyngtoun / nat fer fro Caumbrygge / There goth a broke / and ouer that a brygge
msItem.explicit: 52v: Saue al this companye / grete and smale / Thus haue I quyt the Millere / in my tale
msItem.note: 'quod the Reve' in the margin of f. 52v.

msItem.title: Cook's Prologue
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.rubric: 52v: ...and bigynneth the prologe of the Cook
msItem.incipit: 52v: The Cok of Londoun / while the Reve spak / For ioye him þought / he clawed him on the bak
msItem.explicit: 53r: And ther with alle / he lough and made chere / And seide his tale / as ȝe shuln after here

msItem.title: Cook's Tale
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 53r: A prentys whilom / dwelled in oure Citee / Of a craft / of vetayleres was he
msItem.explicit: 53v: And had a wyf / þat held for countenaunce / A shoppe / and swyued for hire sustenaunce
msItem.note: A 13-line gap follows the end of the text, with the rubric on the following recto.

msItem.title: Introduction to the Man of Law's Tale
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 54r: Oure host saw wel / þat the bright sonne / The ark of his artificiale day / hath ronne
msItem.explicit: 55r: And with that word / he with a sober chere / Bygan his tale / as ȝe shuln after here

msItem.title: Man of Law's Prologue
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 55r: O hateful harme / condicione of pouerte / With thrust with cold / with honger so confounded
msItem.explicit: 55v: Ner that a Marchaunt / gon is many a ȝere / Me taught a tale / which þat ȝe shal here

msItem.title: Man of Law's Tale
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 55v: In Surrye whilom / dwelled a companye / Of chapmen riche / and ther to sad and trewe
msItem.explicit: 67r: Ioye after woo / gouerne vs / in his grace / And kepe vs alle / that ben in this place
msItem.note: Opening rubric added by a later hand.
'Amen quod Wytton' in the margin of f. 67r.

msItem.title: Wife of Bath's Prologue
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 67r: Experience / though noon auctoritee / Were in this world / is right I now for me
msItem.explicit: 76v: If I haue lycence / of this worthy Frere / Ȝis dame quod he / tell forth / and I wyl here

msItem.title: Wife of Bath's Tale
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 76v: In the olde dayes / of kyng Arthour / Of which that Bretons speken / gret honour
msItem.explicit: 81r: And olde and angry / nygardes of despence / God send hem sone / verray pestilence
msItem.finalRubric: 81r: Hic desinit fabula vxoris de Bathe...

msItem.title: Friar's Prologue
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 81r: This worthy Lymytour / this noble frere / He made alwey / a maner louryng chere
msItem.explicit: 81v: And after this / he seide vn to the Frere / Telleth forth ȝoure tale / myn owen maister dere

msItem.title: Friar's Tale
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 81v: Whilom there was dwellyng / in my contree / An Archedekene / a man of hey degree
msItem.explicit: 85v: And preyeth that theise Sompnours / hem repent / Of here mysdedis / or that the fend hem hent

msItem.title: Summoner's Prologue
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 85v: This Sompnour / in hise stiryopes heye stode / Vp on this frere / his hert was so wode
msItem.explicit: 86r: God saue ȝow alle / saue this cursed Frere / My prolog wol I ende / in this manere

msItem.title: Summoner's Tale
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 86r: Lordyngges there is / in ȝorkshire as I gesse / A mersshy contre / called holdernesse
msItem.explicit: 92r: And Iankyn hath I wonne / a newe Govne / My Tale is doon / we ben almost at Tovne
msItem.note: 'quod Wytton' in the margin of f. 92r.
A 9-line gap between the final line and the final rubric.

msItem.title: Clerk's Prologue
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 92v: Sire Clerk of Oxenford / oure host sayde / ȝe ride as stille and coy / as dooth a mayde
msItem.explicit: 93r: Saue he wole conueyen / his matere / But this is the tale / which þat ȝe moun heere

msItem.title: Clerk's Tale
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 93r: There is right at the west side / of Ytaille / Doun at te rote / of vesulus the colde
msItem.explicit: 105v: Be ay of chere as light / as lef on lynde / And late him care / wepe / wrynge / and waille

msItem.title: 'Clerk's Endlink' / 'The Host's Stanza'
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 105v: This worthi clerk / whan ended was his tale / Oure host seyde / and swor by godys bones
msItem.explicit: 105v: As to my purpos / wyst ȝe my wylle / But thyng that wol nat be / lat it be stille

msItem.title: Merchant's Prologue
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 106r: Wepyng and waylyng / care and other sorwe / I knowe I now / on Euen and on morwe
msItem.explicit: 106r: Gladly quod he / but of myn owen sore / For sory hert / I telle may nomore

msItem.title: Merchant's Tale
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 106r: Whilom there was dwellyng / in lumbardie / A worthy knyght / that born was of Pauye
msItem.explicit: 119r: Thus endeth heere my tale / of Ianuarie / God blisse vs alle / and oure lady Seynt Marie

msItem.title: 'Merchant's Endlink'
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 119r: Ey goddis mercy / seide oure hoost tho / Now swich a wyf / I preye god kepe me fro
msItem.explicit: 119v: And eke my wyt / suffiseth nat therto / To tellen al / wherfore my tale is do

msItem.title: 'Squire's Headlink'
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 119v: Squyere come ner / if it ȝoure wylle be / And seye som what of loue / for certes ȝe
msItem.explicit: 119v: Haue me excused / if I speke amys / My wyl is good / and lo my tale is this

msItem.title: Squire's Tale
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 119v: At Sarray / in the lond of Tartarye / There dwelled a kyng / that werred Russye
msItem.explicit: 127r: For Canacee / or that he myght hire wynne . And there I lefte / I wil aȝein begynne
msItem.finalRubric: 127r: Explicit Secunda pars / Here endith the Squyeres tale / as meche as Chaucer made
msItem.note: Remainder of f. 127r and all of f. 127v left blank (with additions made later to the verso).

msItem.title: Franklin's Tale
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 129r: She seide sire / sithe of ȝoure gentillesse / ȝe profre me / to haue so large a reyne
msItem.explicit: 138v: Now telleth me / or that ȝe ferthere wende / I can namore / my tale is at an ende

msItem.title: Physician's Tale
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.rubric: 138v: ...and bigynneth the Phisiciens tale / with outer a Prologe
msItem.incipit: 138v: There was as telleth / Titus liuius / A knyght / that called was Virginius
msItem.explicit: 141v: Therfore I rede ȝow / this counseil take / Forsaketh synne / er synne ȝow forsake

msItem.title: 'Physician-Pardoner Link' / 'The Host's Words'
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.rubric: 141v: ...abd bigynneth the prologe of the Pardonere
msItem.incipit: 142r: Oure hoost bygan to swere / as he were wood / Harrowe quod he / by nayles and by blood
msItem.explicit: 142r: I graunte I wys quod he / but I must thynke / Vpon som honest thyng / whil that I drynke

msItem.title: Pardoner's Prologue
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.rubric: 142r-142v: Radix omnium malorum est Cupiditas ; Ad Thymotheum . 6o | The Pardoners owyn Prologe
msItem.incipit: 142v: Lordynges quod he / in chirches whan I preche / I peyne me to haue / an hauteyn speche
msItem.explicit: 143v: Which I am wont to preche / for to wynne / Now holde ȝoure pees / my tale I wol bigynne
msItem.note: DIMEV: VI.333-4, 346 omitted; spurious lines follow 345.

msItem.title: Pardoner's Tale
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 144r: In Flaundres whilom / was a compaignye / Of ȝonge folk / that haunteden folye
msItem.explicit: 149v: And as we diden / lat vs laughe and pleye / Anoon they kisten / and reden forth here weye
msItem.note: Remainder of f. 149v and all of f. 150r left blank (with additions made later to both).

msItem.title: Shipman's Tale
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.rubric: 150v: Here bigynneth the Shipmans tale / next folwyng the Pardoner
msItem.incipit: 150v: A Marchaunt whilom dwelled / at Seynt Denys / That riche was / for which men helde him wys
msItem.explicit: 154v: Me semed so / as by his countenaunce / But nathelees / by god oure heuene kyng

msItem.title: Prioress's Prologue
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 156r: Lady thyn bountee / thyn magnificence / Thy vertu / and thyn gret humylitee
msItem.explicit: 156r: Right so fare I / and therfore I ȝow preye / Gydeth my song / that I shal of ȝow seye

msItem.title: Prioress's Tale
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.rubric: 156r: Here bigynneth the Prioresse hire Tale
msItem.incipit: 156r: There was in Assye / in a gret Citee / A monges cristene folk / a Iewerie
msItem.explicit: 157v: And seide / o dere child / I halse the / In vertu / of the holy Trynyte

msItem.title: Sir Thopas
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 159r: But he was chast and no lechour / And swete as is the brambel flour / That bereth the red hepe
msItem.explicit: 160r: As dede the knyght Sire Percyuelle / So worthy vnder wede ; Til on a day
msItem.note: DIMEV: VII.712-44 lost. The final line (918) follows 917 in the margin, written as if one line, separated only by a punctus elevatus.
Rhyming couplets accompanied by a brace and a third line of verse.

msItem.title: 'Thopas-Melibee Link'
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 160r: Nomore of this / for goddes dignytee / Quod oure hoost / for thow makest me / So wery / of thyn verray lewednesse
msItem.explicit: 160v: And þerfore herkeneth / what that I shal seye / And lat me tellen al my tale / I preye
msItem.finalRubric: 160v: Here endeth Chaucers tale of Thopas and the prologe of Melibeus...

msItem.title: Tale of Melibee
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 160v: A ȝong man called Melibeus myghty and riche / bygat vpon his wyf / that called was Prudence
msItem.explicit: 177r: þat he wole for ȝeuen vs oure giltes / and bryngen vs to the blisse / that neuere hath ende ; Amen
msItem.finalRubric: 177r: Heere is ended Chaucers tale of Melibe...

msItem.title: Monk's Prologue
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.rubric: 177r: ...and bygynneth the Prologe of the Monks tale
msItem.incipit: 177r: Whan ended was my tale / of Melibe / And of Prudence / and hire benygnetee
msItem.explicit: 178v: As now it cometh / vn to my remembraunce / Haue me excused / of myn ignoraunce

msItem.title: Monk's Tale
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.rubric: 178v: ...and bigynneth þe Monkes tale þat is titled de casibus virorum Illustrium ; Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 178v: I wole be wayle / in manere of tragedie / The harm of hem / þat stoden in hey degree
msItem.explicit: 187r: That hight Daunt / for he can it al deuyse / Fro poynt to poynt / nat oo word wil he faille
msItem.finalRubric: 187r: Here endeth the Monkes Tale / de casibus virorum Illustrium
msItem.note: DIMEV: VII.2375-2462 (the 'Modern Instances') follow 2766; 2380 left blank.

msItem.title: Nun's Priest's Prologue
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.rubric: 187v: Here bigynneth the Prologe of the Nonnes Prest
msItem.incipit: 187v: Hoo quod the knyght / good sire nomore of this / That ȝe han seid / is right I now I wys
msItem.explicit: 187v: Thanne spak oure hoost / with rude speche and bolde / And seide / vnto the Nonnes preest / a noon

msItem.title: Nun's Priest's Tale
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 189r: What eyleth yow to grone / in this manere / Ȝe ben a verrey slepere / fy for shame
msItem.explicit: 195r: As seith my lord / so make vs alle goode men / An brynge vs to his blisse / Amen

msItem.title: 'Nun's Priest's Epilogue'
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 195r: Sire Nonnes Preest / oure hoost seide a noon / I blissed be thy breche / and euery ston
msItem.explicit: 195v: And after that / he with ful merie chere / Seide vn to a nother / as ȝe shuln heere
msItem.finalRubric: 195v: Heere endeth the Tale of the Nonnes Preest...
msItem.note: Gap of c. 15 lines between final line and final rubric

msItem.title: Prologue of the Second Nun's Tale
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.rubric: 195v: ...and bigynneth the Secund Nonnes Tale of Seynt Cecile / With oute a Prologe
msItem.incipit: 195v: The ministre / and the Norice vn to vices / Which þat men clepen / in Englissh ydelnesse
msItem.explicit: 197r: And brennyng euere / in Charite ful brighte / Now haue I ȝow declared / what she highte

msItem.title: Second Nun's Tale
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 197r: This mayden bright / Cecile / as hire lif seith / Was come of Romayns / and of noble kynde
msItem.explicit: 202r: In which / in to this day / in noble wyse / Men don to Crist / and to his seynt seruyse
msItem.finalRubric: 202r: Heere endeth the Secund Nonnes tale...

msItem.title: Canon's Yeoman's Prologue
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.rubric: 202r: ...and bigynneth the Prologe of the Chanouns Ȝeman
msItem.incipit: 202r: Whan that told was / the lyf of Seynt Cecile / Er we had riden fully / fyue myle
msItem.explicit: 204r: Syn þat my lord is gon / I wyl nat spare / Swich thyng as that I knowe / I wil declare
msItem.finalRubric: 204r: Heere endeth the prologe of the Chanouns Ȝeman...
msItem.note: DIMEV: VIII.711 omitted ('deficit versus' in margin); 564-5 precede 562-3.

msItem.title: Canon's Yeoman's Tale
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 204r: With this Chanoun / I dwelt haue seuene ȝere / And of his science / am I neuere the nere
msItem.explicit: 205v: And of bodies / mollificacioun / And also / of here induracion

support.material: Paper quires, with outermost and innermost bifolia formed of parchment. For a detailed description of the paper stocks, see Da Rold, The Dd Manuscript: Materials (2013).

extent.seg: iv + 180 + iv leaves. 36 leaves of parchment or paper have been inserted in place of missing leaves as part of the volume's conservation. See Custodial History for further information. These inserted leaves have not been digitised, with two exceptions, where the remains of a leaf have been incorporated and mis-numbered (f. 37, as '36b'; and f. 188, as '188a').

seg.note: The dimensions here relate to the leaves of paper. Those of parchment are of irregular size and typically smaller than the paper leaves.

foliation.note: Written in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the recto of each leaf, initially by Henry BradshawBradshaw, Henry, 1831-1886, University Librarian 1867-1886. Folio numbers were assigned to leaves no longer present in the volume (as per historic foliation practice at Cambridge University Library). Bradshaw's numbering is most visible in its original form on the leaves of parchment. On the leaves of paper, most of the numbering has been erased and re-written.

Three mistakes were made in the process of refoliation. A stub of a missing leaf that bears no text has been foliated as f. 36b: such stubs ought not to have been foliated at all, and in any case is the remnants of what Bradshaw would have foliated as f. 37. Similarly, what remains of f. 188 has been misnumbered as '188a'. Folio 164 has been misnumbered as '169'. In each instance, these mistakes have been corrected in the digital record and display provided here.
Written in pencil in the centre of the fore-edge margin of the recto of each leaf, probably by Henry BradshawBradshaw, Henry, 1831-1886.

collation.p:
The manuscript comprises 9 quires, all originally of 24 leaves, but most lacking one or more leaves, as follows:
Quire 124-15 (ff. 6-20: 1st-5th, 9th-11th, 14th-16th and 21st-24th leaves all missing)
Quire 224-1 (ff. 26-48: 1st and 13th leaves missing)
Quire 324-2 (ff. 49-72: 12th and 13th leaves missing)
Quires 4-524 (ff. 73-120)
Quire 624-2 (ff. 121-144: 8th and 17th leaves missing)
Quire 724-3 (ff. 145-168: 11th, 14th and 19th leaves missing)
Quire 824-1 (ff. 169-192: 20th leaf missing)
Quire 924-12 (ff. 193-205: 13th-24th leaves missing)

signatures.p: Leaf signatures of various sorts, as follows: Quire 2, ff-m (ff. 30-36); Quire 3, 1-11 (ff. 49-59); Quire 4, A-M (ff. 73-84); Quires 5-9, the typical late medieval alphanumeric sequence, starting a i-a xii, through to d i-d xii (f. 97 onwards).

catchwords.seg: Catchwords, sometimes introduced with a red paraph mark and / or enclosed in a box, or neither.

supportDesc.condition: The edges and corners of the paper leaves at the beginning of the volume (ff. 6-11, 17-27) were damaged and subject to losses, but have since been stabilised and filled. The corners of most of the leaves in the rest of the volume had also been lost through wear and have been treated likewise. See Custodial History for further information.

layout.seg: Paper leaves ruled in harpoint, frame only. Parchment leaves ruled variously in hardpoint (Quire 1), brown ink (Quires 2-3), and ink (Quire 9). The ruling of the parchment in Quires 4-5 is unclear. Single column. 41-48 lines to the page, written below top line. The written space varies in size, being more regular on the leaves of paper (220 x 130-140 mm) than on the leaves of parchment (210-220 x 110-130 mm).

handNote.p: All of the text, rubrics, and corrections are written by a single hand in Anglicana formata, influenced occasionally by Bastard Anglicana, which is used mainly in the rubrics. Signed 'Wytton' on ff. 39r, 47r, 67r and 92r. For a detailed profile and description of the hand, as well as discussion of various theories as to the identification of 'Wytton', see Da Rold, The Dd Manuscript: Palaeographical considerations (2013).

decoDesc.decoNote: Two- to six-line initials in blue, with infill and marginal flourishing in red, at the openings of prologues and tales, and occasionally at intermediate points within.

decoNote.p: Occasional calligraphic treatment of litterae notabiliores. From 113v onwards, at intervals, letters ornamented by elongation and fancy ascenders.
Paraph marks, in red or blue, used throughout, in the text, rubrics and marginal annotations.

note.p: Beginning of a letter written by a later hand on f. 127v. Manly and Rickert (i. p. 104) suggest that it might refer to the visit of Danish ambassadors to London in August 1496.
Quire signatures a-i written in pencil in the lower right-hand corner of the recto side of the first leaf in each quire by 19th-/20th-century hands.

Annotation on f. 201r by Henry BradshawBradshaw, Henry, 1831-1886 ('leaves 200, 201 shd be transposed') and another on f. 199v by H.L. Pink Pink, H. L. ('leaf 200 misbound after 201'). These should now be disregarded. For further details, see Custodial History.

binding.p: Rebound at Cambridge University Library 2004-2007. Alum-tawed skin, dyed yellow, over pasteboards. For further details, see Custodial History.

Rebound in 1862 by Wiseman (bookbinder), Cambridge Wiseman (bookbinder), Cambridge. Brown calf over pasteboards, blind tooled with geometrical designs; sewn on five bands. Title and classmark tooled in gold on the spine. This former is now kept in the drawer of the box in which the manuscript is housed.

Part of the leather from a former binding of the early 17th century (or thereabouts) was preserved and pasted onto the inside of the 19th-century covers. These show a cross with four acorns and oak leaves, tooled in gold, with the initials 'S W' blind-tooled on each side. See Provenance for further discussion.

origin.p: Various theories have been advanced concerning the date and place of production of the manuscript, with Oxford, London, Westminster or some other as yet unknown location each being proposed. See bibliography below.

provenance.p: Much of the medieval and early modern provenance of MS Dd.4.24 remains uncertain. The manuscript contains numerous annotations and inscriptions, often of names - all, some or none of which may be connected with its ownership. Many of the connections between these names and specific individuals were first put forward by John Manly and Edith Rickert (1940), but the evidence is often tenuous and the connections speculative, and they remain the subject of some debate. See Seymour (1997), Mosser (2011) and Da Rold (2013) for further discussion.

Rather than reproduce what was proposed by Manly and Rickert, this description will instead list the locations and approximate dates of the names written into MS Dd.4.24, providing convenient links to these instances and the basis for future research.

8r: 'HungerfordHungerford' (15th century). 'Hungerford' has not been identified. (A 'Margery Hungerford' signed her name in Cambridge, University Library, MS Ff.1.6, f. 14v, however the style of handwriting is different to that used here).
38r: 'Rychard MervynRychard Mervyn' (16th century). Rychard/Richard Mervyn has not been identified.
146r: 'Thys ys Wyllyam Langstuns Boke' (16th century). William Langston/Langdon (16th century) Langston/Langdon, William (16th century) has not been identified.

180r: 'Said william rokes' (16th/17th century). Another inscription on f. 120v might repeat the surname 'rokes'. William Rokes/Rookes (16th/17th century) Rokes/Rookes, William (16th/17th century) has not been identified, though the same name may also be found in Cambridge, University Library, MS Add. 6864.

150r: 'Wyllyam pully ys my name and he' (16th/17th century). William Pully Pully, William (16th/17th century) has not been identified. (A William Pulley was at Trinity College, Cambridge, 1584-91, vicar at various parishes in Kent 1596-1608 onwards. Will proven 1645. See: Venn:PLY584W.

'S W' (16th/17th century). Initials blind-tooled on the covers of an earlier, 16th/17th-century binding, preserved on the front and rear pastedowns of the 19th-century binding (which itself has been replaced and is retained with the manuscript). 'S. W.S. W.' has not been identified. Seymour suggests that the initials could indicate the manuscript's ownership by Samuel Ward (d. 1605)Ward, Samuel (d. 1605) of Ipswich, though on what basis is not made clear, and this connection remains speculative.

acquisition.p: The date and circumstances of the manuscript's acquisition by Cambridge University Library remain unclear. It has not been identified among the manuscripts listed as belonging to John Moore (1646-1714), bishop of Ely Moore, John, 1646-1714 in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697) or the handwritten supplementary list of Moore's manuscripts (now Cambridge, University Library, MS Oo.7.50(2)) compiled by Thomas Tanner (1674-1735). However, it must have arrived by c. 1753, since it was recorded in the handwritten catalogue compiled at that time by Francis Sawyer Parris, Protobibliothecarius (now Cambridge, University Library, MS Oo.7.53-55). It is marked there as 'R', as were other books known or thought to have been among Moore's library. This collection was purchased en bloc and presented to the University Library in 1715 by George I George I, King of Great Britain, 1660-1727 , and known thereafter as the 'Royal Library' (hence, 'R').

If Moore did indeed own this manuscript, Manly and Rickert suggested that he may have obtained it from Samuel Hoadly/HodleyHoadly/Hodley, Samuel, of the grammar school at Hackney, who was noted as having in his possession a copy of 'Chaucer's Works' - though this description does not match the contents of this manuscript and the connection seems doubtful.

recordHist.source:
This catalogue entry draws on:
The Dd Manuscript, ed. by Orietta Da Rold, The Norman Blake Editions of The Canterbury Tales (University of Sheffield, 2013), [http://www.chaucermss.org/dd] [accessed 19 February 2024] (used here by kind permission of the author).
Daniel W. Mosser, 'A digital catalogue of the pre-1500 manuscripts and incunables of the Canterbury Tales', 2nd edition (2011), [https://www.mossercatalogue.net/record.php?recID=Dd]
The Digital Index of Middle English Verse, ed. by Linne R. Mooney, Daniel W. Mosser and Elizabeth Solopova (2008-)
An unpublished description of the manuscript composed between 1948 and 1970 by H.L. Pink Pink, H. L., now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/75).
An unpublished description of the manuscript composed between 1926 and 1930 by M.R. James James, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862-1936, now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/74).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

custodialHist.custEvent: The manuscript was disbound, conserved and rebound 2004-2007 by Kristine RoseBeers, Kristine Rose. For details of the treatments and materials used, see The Dd Manuscript: The conservation of Dd.4.24 by Kristine Rose. Prior to this, the two leaves following f. 199 were bound in reverse order. This was corrected during rebinding and the leaves renumbered, in order that both the text and the foliation sequence run correctly.
